key_points: Kyle Rittenhouse, 18, was acquitted of all charges for fatally shooting two men and wounding another during protests in Kenosha, Wisconsin.
The verdict concluded a deeply divisive trial that ignited a national debate over vigilantism, gun rights, and self-defense.
Rittenhouse cried and hugged his lawyers after the jury's verdict was read, declaring him not guilty on multiple counts.
The jury's decision came after approximately 26 hours of deliberation, accepting that Rittenhouse acted in self-defense.
Rittenhouse became a national symbol, with some viewing him as a vigilante and others as a defender of peace.
Political figures and the public reacted strongly to the verdict, with opinions split along ideological lines.
Governor Gavin Newsom criticized the verdict, while President Biden expressed concern but urged for peaceful acceptance.
Mark Richards, Rittenhouse's defense lawyer, stated Rittenhouse looks forward to moving on with his life post-verdict.
The trial examined the events of August 25, 2020, when Rittenhouse, armed and claiming to offer medical aid, shot three people amid unrest in Kenosha.
The prosecution attempted to portray Rittenhouse as an instigator, while the defense and verdict supported the notion of self-defense.
spokespersons: Rebecca Kleefisch (Republican candidate for Wisconsin governor)
